instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-00426: What is 820-00426? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.ALL_SYS_PWRGD: What is ALL_SYS_PWRGD? ALL_SYS_PWRGD is present when PP1V8_S3, PP5V_S3, PP1V2_S3, PP1V05_S0, PP5V_S0, PP3V3_S0, & PP1V5_S0 are present and working. If any of these rails is not working, ALL_SYS_PWRGD will be pulled down and the machine will not turn on. .
definitions.SMC_LID: What is SMC_LID? SMC_LID tells the machine the system is open when it is 3.3v to 3.4v, and closed when it is low such as 0v-0.6v. When this signal is low, the machine may go to sleep or have no backlight. .
definitions.LCD_BKLT_EN: What is LCD_BKLT_EN? This is an enable signal. Anytime you see “_EN”, it means when the voltage is high(3.3 volts), whatever it is going to is being turned on or enabled. Here, “LCD_BKLT” which stands for “LCD screen backlight” is being enabled. This signal usually goes to an LED driver used for creating a power rail for the LCD screen backlight, to tell it to turn on & create this rail. .
definitions.LCD_PWR_EN: What is LCD_PWR_EN? LCD_PWR_EN is a signal that tells the chip that supplies power to the LCD screen to turn on..
definitions.PP5V5_S5: What is PP5V5_S5? This is a typo of PP5V_S5 When you see PP5V_S5, assume they meant to type PP5V_S5.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 3 seconds then turns off
threads.message:
So this board initially had corrosion around the Thunderbolt boost regulator  L3095 and <TRANSISTOR>Q3088</TRANSISTOR>.

After an ultrasonic the board seems to come to life .. fan spins for a few seconds (between 3 and 5) then it's back into an S5 state.

This seems a very different problem to the 1/4 fan spin mentioned frequently in the forums.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 3 seconds then turns off
threads.message:
Try to start in SMC bypass first.
Also try removing <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 3 seconds then turns off
threads.message: Oh wow <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR> has disintegrated - ill clean up that mess and report back

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 3 seconds then turns off
threads.message: Hmmm no change ... <TRANSISTOR>Q3080</TRANSISTOR> gone and starting in SMC bypass makes no difference.  It's running for a good 6 seconds then hard fan stop.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 3 seconds then turns off
threads.message: Probing on <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>CPUVR_GOOD</SIGNAL> are falling to 0v at pretty much the same time

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 3 seconds then turns off
threads.message: Monitor all power rails; big coils and pages 64/66 too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 3 seconds then turns off
threads.message: Found another area of crud on the board - the hall effect pads.  <RESISTOR>R5250</RESISTOR> has jumped off the board.   <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> should be high yes ?

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 3 seconds then turns off
threads.message: <SIGNAL>SMC_LID</SIGNAL> is now fixed .. still no change in behavior

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 3 seconds then turns off
threads.message:
You should have more corroded components.
Check all voltages, as above mentioned.

You may need to reball SMC; maybe heat PCH and CPU with quality flux too.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 3 seconds then turns off
threads.message:
Going through all of this now - I may be a little while. 

Wish I knew more about the start-up sequence after the S0 state.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 3 seconds then turns off
threads.message:
More fun and games !

Having spent some time with the scope this is where I am.

- On start up the fan stutters, makes a spin, stops then starts up for approx 6 seconds.  <SIGNAL>PP5V5_S5</SIGNAL> drops to 0v for approx 100ms before raising back to 5.5v 
- While the system is running for the 6 seconds or so all voltages are rock solid EXCEPT anything GPU/LCD related - but i'm not sure at what point in the start up sequence we would expect to see this enabled

e.g.

L8760 0v 
L8710 0v
<SIGNAL>LCD_PWR_EN</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>LCD_BKLT_EN</SIGNAL> 0v

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 3 seconds then turns off
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 3 seconds then turns off
threads.message: And for that i'm going to need to spend the ??? (or Euros) on a Medusa -

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 3 seconds then turns off
threads.message:
Don't you have a normal USB programmer???
Of course, you need to remove the chip from the board.

If you really plan to stay in business with Apple stuff, then spend that money; because time is money...

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 3 seconds then turns off
threads.message: Amazing .. a bios flash worked! ... took me way too long to work out how to do this.  Wrong tools for the job really.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> - <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-00426</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> Fan spins for 3 seconds then turns off
threads.message:
Be sure the BIOS flashed had clean ME region; to avoid any future issue.
I suppose you didn't change serial number with original from back cover; fix checksum of Fsys area in BIOS is required in such case.
